thread.title: Woodard, Rutland knock off Mount Mansfield
thread.title_full: Woodard, Rutland knock off Mount Mansfield

title: Woodard, Rutland knock off Mount Mansfield
text:
Woodard, Rutland knock off Mount Mansfield Austin Danforth , Free Press Staff Writer 11:15 p.m. EDT October 24, 2015 Buy Photo Rutland's Brooke Woodard, left, fires a shot past Mount Mansfield's Laura McKenzie (21) during the second half of Saturday's girls soccer playoff game in Jericho. (Photo: AUSTIN DANFORTH/FREE PRESS) Buy Photo 1 CONNECT 9 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
JERICHO - Twelve months ago, with just two wins on its resume, the Rutland High School girls soccer team tasted the early, lopsided postseason defeat that so often accompanies the No. 15 seed. 
What's changed in a year? 
Almost everything. 
Thanks to Brooke Woodard's spectacular breakthrough goal in the 66th minute, the fifth-seeded Raiders are headed to the Division I semifinals for the first time in nearly a decade after ousting No. 4 Mount Mansfield 1-0 on Saturday. 
"It's a testament to these girls," said Rutland coach Lori McClallen. "The makeup of our team is different — girls that work harder in practice, the team chemistry is there, girls that understand the game better than the team we had last year. 
"But really it's the hard work they've put in, to come to practice every day to want to get better." 
Since falling to the Cougars 3-0 in a Sept. 11 showdown, the Raiders (11-5) have now won nine of their last 11 games. Saturday's quarterfinal tilt had little chance to finish as one-sided as the teams' first meeting. 
"We got a great result down there on the road, 3-0, but we knew it wasn't going to be anything like that," MMU coach Eric Barker said. Buy Photo 
Mount Mansfield's Macey Wissell (13) heads a shot toward the Rutland goal during the first half of Saturday's girls soccer playoff game in Jericho. (Photo: AUSTIN DANFORTH/FREE PRESS) 
The Raiders' two losses? A chance for payback awaits in Tuesday's semifinal against top-seeded Burr and Burton (16-0). 
"It's really exciting for us. Last year we were pretty bummed, we didn't want to play in that game," Woodard said of her team's 11-0 playdown loss to eventual state champion Champlain Valley. "But now we're all excited to play, all want to keep practicing and playing with each other." 
And Rutland gets to do just that after the moment of brilliance the junior forward displayed late in the second half. 
Collecting Jordan DelBianco's ball in the left side of the 18-yard box, Woodard sized up her options with a defender on her back and two others behind her. 
Woodard spun away from the first and then dragged the ball backwards, away from the second, with the bottom of her right foot. A touch with her left foot split the last two defenders with enough room to rifle a near-post shot past MMU goalie Emma Parent (seven saves). 
"It was probably the best sole-reverse I've ever seen in the girls game," Barker said. 
Like that, the Raiders had the only goal they needed. 
"You give Brooke a ball at her feet, you're inside the box, she'll do what she can to get that ball in the back of the net," McClallen said. "One girl, two girls, it doesn't matter. She'll find a way to get it in there." 
Woodard's presence alone — the footwork in tight spaces, the ability to turn a clearance into a counter with a weaving, 40-yard run — had the Cougars (10-6) wary from the start. 
"We had to play the game with an eye on Brooke — and that's really it," Barker said. "When you have to look at the other team to make sure you're taking care of that, it kind of takes you a little bit out of your steps, what you want to accomplish out there." 
Barker and the Cougars switched the player tasked with marking Woodard at halftime, opting for a defender rather than a midfielder, and the contest opened up almost immediately.
